review.title: An Efficient Metric of Automatic Weight Generation for Properties in Instance Matching Technique
review.abstract: The proliferation of heterogeneous data sources of semantic knowledge base intensifies the need of an automatic instance matching technique. However, the efficiency of instance matching is often influenced by the weight of a property associated to instances. Automatic weight generation is a non-trivial, however an important task in instance matching technique. Therefore, identifying an appropriate metric for generating weight for a property automatically is nevertheless a formidable task. In this paper, we investigate an approach of generating weights automatically by considering hypotheses: (1) the weight of a property is directly proportional to the ratio of the number of its distinct values to the number of instances contain the property, and (2) the weight is also proportional to the ratio of the number of distinct values of a property to the number of instances in a training dataset. The basic intuition behind the use of our approach is the classical theory of information content that infrequent words are more informative than frequent ones. Our mathematical model derives a metric for generating property weights automatically, which is applied in instance matching system to produce re-conciliated instances efficiently. Our experiments and evaluations show the effectiveness of our proposed metric of automatic weight generation for properties in an instance matching technique.

sections.heading: 5. OUR INSTANCE MATCHING SYSTEM
sections.text: Our primitive instance matching system [13, 29] did not receive the essence of automatic weight generation. Nevertheless, we consider the system to be the core of our advanced approach. Our primitive instance matching system contains: 1. Ontology Alignment Modules, 2. Semantic Link Cloud (SLC) Generation Modules and 3. Instance Matching Algorithm.

sections.heading: 5.1. Ontology Alignment
sections.text: A concept is neither complete nor explicit in its own words. Therefore, concepts are organized in a semantic network or taxonomy linked to a number of relationships in order to explicitly define them to avoid polysemitic problems. Our ontological schema matching algorithm [30, 13, 31] takes into account the nature of reference localization by taking into account adjacent concepts and relationships to harmonize the units of ontology.Our ontology algorithm of alignment begins with a seed point called an anchor, where the concept anchor is a pair of "similar" concepts from each of two ontologies. Starting from an anchor point, our scalable algorithm collects two sets of adjacent concepts across ontologies. Since our algorithm starts an anchor and examines adjacent concepts, it does not depend much on the size of the ontologies.

sections.heading: 5.2. SLC Generation Module
sections.text: Semantic Link Cloud (SLC), the collection of linked information from an instance, is an important step toward instance matching. Users often describe an instance in different ways and even through different but adjacent concepts of an ontology, often resulting in undetected or misaligned pairs. ABox's collection of semantically linked resources, as well as TBox's concepts or properties, specifies an instance at sufficient depth to identify instances in a different location or with entirely different designations. Therefore, our proposed method collects all linked information from a particular instance as a reference point. The linked information is defined as concepts, properties or their values that are directly related to the reference instance, and is referred to a semantic left cloud.

sections.text: The strength of our instance matching algorithm mainly depends on the efficiency of generating SLC and adapting the ontological schema. sections.heading: 6. PERFORMANCE EVALUATION
sections.text: We are conducting a series of experiments with IIMB data sets from the 2009 and 2010 versions and evaluating them with evaluation metrics.

sections.heading: 6.1. Data sets
sections.text: A generated benchmark to test the efficiency of an instance comparison is called the ISLab Instance Matching Benchmark (IIMB). 2. The test booth provides OWL / RDF data on actors, sports people and business companies. We have used two different versions of IIMB data sets: 2009 version and 2010 version. In 2009 version, the main directory contains 37 subdirectories and the original ABox and the associated TBox (abox.owl and tbox.owl). The original ABox contains about 222 different distances with a number of associated property values. Each subdirectory contains a modified ABox (abox.owl + tbox.owl) and the corresponding image with the instances in the original ABox (refalign.rdf). The benchmark data is divided into four large groups: value transformation (001-010), structural transformation (020-029), logical transformation (020-033) and a large transformation (033-033).

sections.heading: 6.2. Evaluation Metrics
sections.text: In the instance matching experiment, we performed evaluations with respect to precision, callback, and f-measure as defined below: • Precision, P: It is the ratio of the number of correctly detected aligned pairs to the total number of detected aligned pairs. • Callback, R: It is defined as the ratio of the number of correctly detected aligned pairs to the total number of correctly detected aligned pairs. • F-measure: It is a measure to combine precision, P, and callback, R as (2 * P * R) / (P + R).

The basic intuition behind the use of our approach is the classical theory of information content that infrequent words are more informative than frequent ones. Our mathematical model derives a metric for generating property weights automatically, which is applied in instance matching system to produce re-conciliated instances efficiently. Our experiments and evaluations show the effectiveness of our proposed metric of automatic weight generation for properties in an instance matching technique.
